chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should set a universal minimum guarantee—access to primary, preventive, mental-health, and emergency care with strong protection from catastrophic costs—so no one is denied care or bankrupted by illness. Within that floor, people should be able to choose among competing public and private plans and providers, with clear rules that enforce price transparency, fair billing, and quality standards. Funding and oversight should reward outcomes, reduce administrative complexity, and strengthen rural and safety-net systems so access improves without open-ended spending.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a clear baseline of affordable, high-quality healthcare for everyone—especially preventive, primary, and emergency care—so no one faces financial ruin due to illness. That guarantee should be delivered with transparent funding, streamlined administration, and strong accountability for cost and outcomes, while preserving the doctor–patient relationship and room for private providers and insurers to compete and innovate. Targeted subsidies and simple enrollment can close coverage gaps, with added support for local hospitals and rural communities to ensure reliable access.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should guarantee a clear baseline of affordable, high-quality healthcare for every resident—especially preventive, emergency, and mental-health care—so no one is denied treatment or pushed into financial ruin. It should fund and oversee this safety net with transparent rules, strong cost controls, and outcome-based accountability, while allowing private insurers and providers to compete and innovate so people can keep meaningful choice and the doctor–patient relationship. Targeted subsidies and simpler enrollment should close gaps for low-income families, rural communities, and seniors, while reducing administrative waste and encouraging personal responsibility for healthy behaviors.
